When you visit historic places like churches, you're [k]expected to[/k] wear appropriate clothes.

Let's have a look at some words we can use to talk about places we've visited or moved to. Make sure to focus on the example phrases to learn some expressions that we can use to describe a country's or region's culture.

To say that two things are equal in some way, we say that something is "as" + adjective + "as" something else. When we talk about equal quantities, we say "as many" + noun + "as". Let's look at some examples:
Seville is one of the most [k]picturesque[/k] places I've ever seen.
Seville is one of the most picturesque places I've ever seen.
There are many [k]lively[/k] areas in the old town.
Match the words with their definitions.
Berlin has a cosmopolitan feel.
There are more
When you visit [k]historic[/k] places like churches, you're expected to wear appropriate clothes.
She liked Colombia more than Peru.
Haggis is a [k]traditional[/k] Scottish dish, but not everyone likes it.
crowded

We use comparative adjectives to talk about differences between two or more things.
In this unit we will practise forming sentences with comparatives, and use them to talk about our travels. Let's have a look at some examples.
We saw such [k]picturesque[/k] places on our trip, it felt like a dream.
This sentence is comparing two hotels.
Select the phrase that has no comparative adjective.
We can use "more / less ... than" to compare nouns to each other. We use "fewer" instead of "less" when the noun is countable.
When you visit historic places like churches, you're expected to wear appropriate clothes.
a train is faster than a bus
Think of two places you have visited. Tell us how they were similar or different experiences. Write in the box or record yourself speaking.
polluted
I would never have thought that...
Don't forget!
Our trip to Peru was [k]as wonderful as[/k] our trip to Colombia!
There are more bicycles in Amsterdam than in Warsaw.
Select the word that can refer to long established routines or customs of a culture.
Priya enjoyed her visit to the Louvre.

full of people

"Picturesque" means something is as beautiful as a great painting.

The example phrases we've seen are a good way of describing a place in greater detail. Have a look below to see these phrases again on their own:
The film is better than the book.

I went to Paris and Tokyo last year. Tokyo was more cosmopolitan than Paris.

Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
I am happier today than I was yesterday.
We form comparatives in two different ways: 1. one-syllable adjective + "-er" ending + "than" 2. "more/less" + adjective of 2 or more syllables + "than"
The Plaza del Sol was [k]crowded[/k].
We saw many people in [k]traditional[/k] dresses.
bad - "worse"
nosy
Our last trip was [k]more[/k] enjoyable than this one.
cosmopolitan
Food in Italy is better than food in the U.K.
lively

The tourist attractions were busy.

lovely

Adjectives ending in "-y" change their ending to "-ier" in a comparison.
When an adjective ends in a vowel + a consonant, we double that consonant before adding "-er".
happy - happier
